text: Cast thy burden upon the LORD, and he shall sustain thee: he shall never suffer the righteous to be moved.
text_kjv: Cast thy burden upon the LORD, and he shall sustain thee: he shall never suffer the righteous to be moved.
text_niv: Cast your cares on the Lordand he will sustain you;he will never let the righteous fall.
text_esv: Cast your burden on the LORD, and he will sustain you; he will never permit the righteous to be moved.
text_nlt: Give your burdens to the LORD,and he will take care of you.He will not permit the godly to slip and fall.
text_msg: Pile your troubles on God's shoulders—he'll carry your load, he'll help you out.He'll never let good peopletopple into ruin.
text_nasb: Cast your burden upon the LORD and He will sustain you; He will never allow the righteous to be shaken.
context: Psalm 55 is attributed to David, likely written during a period of intense personal betrayal and political turmoil, possibly during the rebellion of his son Absalom. The historical context is crucial to understanding the depth of David’s anguish. He laments the treachery of a close friend and advisor, a trusted confidant who turned against him. The Psalm reveals David's emotional vulnerability as he grapples with feelings of abandonment, fear, and a sense of injustice. David's cries for deliverance are set against the backdrop of conspiracy and violence, indicating a period of significant instability in his kingdom. The phrase 'burden' (Hebrew: *yehâb*) in this verse would resonate deeply with the audience of the time, as life was often fraught with physical labor, social obligations, and the constant threat of war. Daily life was precarious and uncertain. The cultural understanding was that strong men, particularly kings, should be self-sufficient. David's open admission of his 'burden' and his plea to cast it upon the Lord are striking for their display of vulnerability and reliance on God in a world where self-reliance was prized. The reference to the 'righteous' being sustained reflects the prevalent belief in divine justice and protection for those who remain faithful to God's covenant.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 55:22 encapsulates a profound truth about God's character and our relationship with Him. The imperative 'Cast thy burden upon the LORD' is an invitation to relinquish our anxieties, worries, and heavy loads to God's care. The word 'burden' isn’t limited to physical labor or material hardship; it encompasses the emotional, spiritual, and mental weights that weigh us down. This act of 'casting' implies a conscious and intentional release of control, acknowledging our limitations and God's omnipotence. The promise that 'He shall sustain thee' speaks to God's active involvement in our lives. 'Sustain' (Hebrew: *kûl*) implies not merely passive support, but active nourishment, preservation, and upholding. God doesn't just offer a temporary fix; He provides ongoing strength and support. The assurance that 'He shall never suffer the righteous to be moved' is a cornerstone of faith. 'Moved' suggests instability, defeat, or being uprooted. This doesn't guarantee a life free from challenges or suffering, but it promises that the righteous, those who strive to live according to God's will, will not be ultimately defeated. They will remain steadfast in their faith, anchored in God's unwavering love and faithfulness. This verse reinforces the concept of divine sovereignty and the believer's dependence on God. It's a testament to God's promise to uphold those who trust in Him, even amidst the storms of life. It aligns with other scriptures that emphasize God’s protection and care for His people.
application: In modern life, Psalm 55:22 offers a powerful antidote to the pervasive anxiety and stress that define our times. We live in a world characterized by relentless pressure, demanding schedules, and constant exposure to information. The 'burden' we carry today manifests in various forms: financial worries, relationship conflicts, career pressures, health concerns, and spiritual doubts. This verse encourages us to actively acknowledge these burdens and to intentionally 'cast' them upon the Lord. Practically, this means incorporating prayer and intentional surrender into our daily routines. It involves confessing our anxieties to God, trusting in His wisdom and power to handle situations beyond our control, and relinquishing the illusion of self-sufficiency. Instead of internalizing our struggles, we are called to present them to God, seeking His guidance and peace. This may involve journaling our concerns, actively listening for God's voice through scripture and prayer, and seeking wise counsel from trusted Christian mentors. The promise of 'sustaining' us means that God doesn't simply take our burdens away; He empowers us to carry them with grace and strength. He provides the emotional, mental, and spiritual resources we need to navigate difficult situations. The assurance that we will not be 'moved' speaks to the resilience and stability that faith provides. Even when circumstances are overwhelming, we can find solace in the knowledge that God is our anchor. This doesn't mean we won't experience pain or setbacks, but it means we won't be ultimately defeated. We can stand firm in our faith, knowing that God is working all things together for our good. Applying this verse requires consistent practice and a willingness to trust God's character, even when we don't understand His plans.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you today acknowledging the burdens I carry. The weight of [mention specific burden(s)] feels heavy, and I confess that I often try to manage it on my own. I now choose to cast these burdens upon you, trusting in your promise to sustain me. Give me the strength to relinquish control and to rest in your peace. Help me to see your hand at work in my life, even when circumstances are difficult. Fill me with your grace and wisdom, that I may navigate these challenges with resilience and faith. Thank you for your unwavering love and your promise to never let me be moved. I trust in your perfect plan for my life. In Jesus’ name, Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'cast' your burden means intentionally releasing your worries, anxieties, and problems to God. It's an act of surrender, acknowledging your limitations and trusting in God's power to handle what you cannot. This involves prayer, confession, and a willingness to relinquish control.
faqs.question: What does it mean to 'cast' my burden on the Lord?

faqs.answer: No, this verse doesn't promise a life free from problems. Instead, it promises that God will sustain you *through* your problems. He will provide the strength, comfort, and wisdom needed to endure and overcome challenges, ultimately keeping you from being defeated.
faqs.question: Does this verse mean God will remove all my problems?

faqs.answer: In this context, 'righteous' refers to those who strive to live according to God's will and commandments. It doesn't mean being perfect, but rather having a heart that seeks to honor God and live in obedience to His Word. It's about being in right relationship with God.
faqs.question: What does it mean to be 'righteous' in this context?

faqs.answer: You know you're truly casting your burden on the Lord when you experience a release of anxiety and a growing sense of peace, despite the ongoing challenges. It's marked by a willingness to trust God's plan, even when it doesn't align with your own desires.
faqs.question: How do I know if I'm truly 'casting' my burden on the Lord?

faqs.answer: It's common to struggle with repeatedly taking back burdens. Recognize this tendency and gently redirect your thoughts back to God. Practice consistent prayer and meditation on scripture to strengthen your trust and reliance on Him. Seek support from other believers.
faqs.question: What if I keep taking the burden back after casting it?
